channel.title: MYB
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from MYB, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Nobel Prize Awarded For Basic Research Into Immune Tolerance
item.description: The 2025 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was started by three researchers for their contributions to our understanding of immune tolerance.

item.title: Rivian Chief Sounds Optimistic About His EV Trucks Despite Headwinds
item.description: The founder and CEO of electric-truck maker Rivian remains optimistic despite headwinds facing electric vehicles.

item.title: Google Suddenly Raises Trade In Prices In New Pixel 10 Giveaway
item.description: Google is building up to its Black Friday pricing with a new Pixel 10 freebie giveaway.

item.title: 3 Things A Climate Scientist Learned From Jane Goodall
item.description: What a climate scientist learned from Dr. Jane Goodall.

item.title: Memory Giant Lexar Announces High Speed Magnetic SSD For iPhone 17 Series
item.description: The Lexar ES5 SSD magnetically attaches to an iPhone and is available in capacities up to 4TB. It supports Apple ProRes at 4K 120fps and Samsung Pro V...

item.title: The grid
item.description: We talk about networks but we are rarely clear about what we mean. A specific sort of network is the grid, and even that idea is complicated by two co...

item.title: Status vs. goodness
item.description: It’s easy to come to the conclusion that people with means and high cultural status choose things that are better. Organic vegetables instead of junk ...

item.title: The questions before the questions
item.description: “I’m applying to work at Disney, do you know anyone who can give me a reference…” “My two partners and I are planning a new company, can we ask you fo...

item.title: Two kinds of confrontations
item.description: When we win by having someone else lose, we set up a conflict. It’s clear, direct but not generative. But when we win by confronting our fear, everyon...

item.title: Reciprocity
item.description: Our biggest commitments, the things we are most dedicated to, rarely pay us back in equal measure. That might be the point.
